intro.title: interactoMIX
intro.main:
The InteractoMIX is the result of the combined efforts of Structural Bioinformatics and Bioinsilico to deliver a unique, one-stop, web portal to centralize a wide-range of computational tools to exploit interactomics data.
InteractoMIX features a set of tools designed to address two majors aspects in the study of protein-protein interactions (PPIs):
  1. What proteins interact. That is, the study of PPIs as a network of interactions including integration of interactomics data, characterization, prediction and application to drug discovery.
  2. How proteins interact. That is, the structural details of PPIs, including characterization of protein interfaces, prediction of sites, docking and peptide design
The different tools compiled in InteractoMIX facilitates the in silico study of some of the top topics in the current biomedical research in PPIs on a user-friendly and intuitive manner. Both computational and experimental scientist can expand their knowledge on explicit pathways (in which their proteins of interest are involved), identify key residues related to the function of a particular interaction, model the structure of protein complexes and, eventually, predict new therapeutic targets and its corresponding agents including the de novo modeling of orthosteric peptides to target particular PPIs.

biana.title: BIANA
biana.main: Biologic Interactions And Network Analysis: BIANA is a integration and network management framework of interactomics data. The integration protocol uses a high level abstraction schema where any data source: a database of interactomics data (e.g. IntAct), included in BIANA is defined as an external database, where both participants and relations are considered as external entities, characterized by several attributes. BIANA's unique unification protocol, a set of rules that determine how data in various data sources are combined, and its traceability, i.e. the attributes contained in each unified entity can always be traced back to its original source. This properties allow BIANA to offer the possibility to the user to create its own unification protocols, a feature missing in most database unification frameworks.
biana.aim: BIANA provides a platform for data integration of diverse public data sources, hence the most complete interactome, and keep a constant track on the data sources.
biana.in: Once a new experiment is created, users have to provide a list of protein identifiers as seeds to the requested PPI network. Users can select several network and experimental related parameters to further personalize the query and request for specific attributes to be fullfiled during search.
biana.out: BIANA provides the user with the network created from the query seed proteins according to the requested network attributes. Furthermore, it provides, for each entity and relation, all the extra data requested by the user. All the data can be downloaded and explored either visually or through applications shuch as Cytoscape.

bips.title: BIPS
bips.main: The BIANA Interolog Prediction Server: BIPS is a tool designed to predict of PPIs based on interologs. The interolog hypothesis implies that two proteins (A and B) are predicted to interact if a known interaction between two proteins (A’ and B’) exists, such that A is similar to A’ and B similar to B’. The server benefits from the integration capabilities of BIANA to use a large data set of experimentally identified PPIs. Furthermore, it exploits additional information such as gene ontology (GO) terms, clusters of orthologous genes or taxonomy, which gives the user the freedom to restrict the predictions according to selected features.
bips.aim: Protein-protein interaction predictions based on interologs.
bips.in: Users must provide a list of query proteins either in FASTA format or a list of standard protein identifiers.
bips.out:
The output is a list of predictions that can be viewed or downloaded. Users can browse the data associated with the predicted partners and select several parameters to estimate the reliability of the predictions such as:
  1. Sequence similarity measures.
  2. Domain–domain interactions.
  3. Common GO terms between the predicted partners.
  4. Clusters of orthologous genes for the prediction.
  5. Experimental method of the template interaction
  6. Taxonomy

iloops.title: iLoops
iloops.main: iLoops is a tool to predict PPIs based on local structural features classified on ArchDB's classification of super-secondary structures (Smotifs). The iLoops Server exploits the funnel-like intermolecular energy landscape theory by mapping information of known PPIs and known non-interacting proteins (NPIs) to predict new protein-protein interactions.
iloops.aim: Assess the probability of a pair of proteins to interact (PPI) or not interact (NPI).
iloops.in: Users must provide a set of FASTA protein sequences and up to 25 interactions to test. Complementary parameters can be selected depending on the user's interests.
iloops.out: For each requested protein-protein relation, the server provides a boolean prediction as if the relation is PPI or NPI. Furthermore, each prediction can be explored as to examine Smotif relations that statistically favourable or disfavourable to the interaction.

guildify.title: GUILDify
guildify.main: GUILDify is a network-based computational tool designed to uncover disease-gene associations and thus increase the understanding of the genes involved in various biological processes and disease phenotypes. GUILDify combines GUILD, graph-based guilt-by-association algorithm and the interactomic data compiled in BIANA to rank genes in the interactome for their relevance to a phenotype of interest. For a given phenotype, it finds genes associated with the phenotype and ranks all other genes based on the connectedness to known disease-genes within the interactome, facilitating the discovery of novel disease-gene associations.
guildify.aim: The server is designed for biomedical researchers working either in dry or wet lab seeking an initial set of genes associated with a certain phenotype or a ranked list of genes potentially linked to the phenotype of interest.
guildify.in: Users only needs to provide the keywords describing the phenotype of interest and select the species to be queried for matching proteins.
guildify.out: A table with the ranking (GUILD scores) of all the proteins in the interactome are provided together with an interactive visualization of the top-scoring network. All the data can be downloaded for further study.

modlink.title: ModLink<sup>+</sup>
modlink.main: ModLink+ is a web server that allows modelling the structure of a given query protein provided its sequence. It combines advanced remote homology detection tools together with known and inferred interactomic data, as unified in BIANA and predicted by BIPS, respectively. The use of PPIs allows ModLink+ to select the correct structural template to model-build the query protein, even when the sequence similarity between the query and the template is low.
modlink.aim: The main use of ModLink+ is to provide a series of three-dimensional models of the tertiary structure of a particular protein.
modlink.in: Users have to provide the sequence of the protein of interest, in FASTA format, and select the preferred method to detect homologous templates. Additionally, users can also provide a list of sequences, in FASTA format, for proteins known to interact with the query.
modlink.out: The server returns the models of the best structural domains that could be assigned to the query together with the corresponding lists of the PPIs that allowed assigning the different structural domains.

vorffip.title: VORFFIP
vorffip.main: The Voronoi Random Forest Feedback Interface Predictor Server is a structure-based computational method for the prediction of protein binding. It makes use of several residue features and a new definition of residue environment by means of Voronoi Diagrams that are integrated by a two-steps Random Forest predictor. The method scores the residues of protein structures and evaluates what regions are more likely to interact with other proteins, i.e. its interface(s).
vorffip.aim: VORFFIP is the tool of selection to predict protein interfaces.
vorffip.in: The basic input required is the atomic coordinates of the query prostein in PDB format. Users can also select the training set tailored specifically for hetero- and homo-dimer interactions and the information on the reliability of the experimental B-factors of the structure.
vorffip.out: A bespoken Jmol panel is given to the user showing the mapping the VORFFIP scores onto the query protein. Scores and a file containing the atomic coordinates of the protein in PDB format with a re-calculated B-factor (showing VORFFIP scores) are readily available for download.

mvorffip.title: M-VORFFIP
mvorffip.main: Multi-VORFFIP is a structure-based, machine learning, computational method designed to predict protein-protein, protein-peptide, protein-DNA and protein-RNA binding sites. M-VORFFIP integrates a wide and heterogeneous set of residue- and environment-based information using a two-step Random Forest ensemble classifier.
mvorffip.aim: A typical use of M-VORFFIP is the prediction of functional sites in proteins including  protein-, peptide-, DNA-, RNA-binding sites that can be used to guide experimental efforts such as the functional mapping of sites in proteins or directed mutagenesis.
mvorffip.in: Users need to provide the atomic coordiantes of the protein of interest in PDB format
mvorffip.out: A bespoken Jmol viewer allows simultaneous, side-by-side, visualization of the four different predictions mapped onto the target protein: protein-, peptide-, DNA- and RNA-binding sites. All the data can be also downloaded by the user for further study.

vdock.title: V-D<sup>2</sup>OCK
vdock.main: V-D2OCK is guide-docking algorithm to model quaternary structure of binary protein complexes. V-D2OCK uses VORFFIP to predict protein interfaces to guide PatchDock to perform directed dockings. Finally, the predicted docking poses are structurally clustered
vdock.aim: The server is of interest for users who, given the structure of two individual monomers, want to model the quaternary structure of the protein complex. Given its relative speed, it is specially suitable for large-scale docking studies.
vdock.in: V-D<sup>2</sup>OCK requires two PDB coordinate files to perform the docking. Additionally, the user can select extra scoring functions, the ability to add hydrogens and the tolerance of the clustering.
vdock.out: The server provides a tables detailing different aspect of predicted complexes as well as Jsmol applets to visualize and manipulate the structures. As with the other servers, all the generated data can be downloaded by the user for further exploring.

pipred.title: PiPreD
pipred.main: PiPreD, is a novel, structure- and knowledge-based, approach to model the conformation of orthosteric peptides to target protein interfaces. It relies on a library of structural motifs derived from interfaces and it uses native structural elements of the target-interface. The search and sampling of peptides covers the entire interface without biases in term of specific regions or peptide conformations
pipred.aim: The most relevant application of PiPreD would be scientist interested in developing peptides to to target specific interactions in protein complexes. These peptides, once experimentally validated, can represent the starting point for the development of novel therapeutic agents or lab reagents.
pipred.ext: Contrary to the rest of the tools in the InteractoMIX suite, the computational requirements of PiPreD makes it difficult to provide the service as a web-app. Thus, a guide is provided for the local installation of the software.

pcrpidb.title: PCRPi-DB
pcrpidb.main: As an extension to PCRPi-W, the PCRPi-DataBase compiles all annotated hot-spots predicted in known protein complexes in the Protein Data Bank. The database is weekly updated coinciding with the release of new protein structures in the PDB.
pcrpidb.aim: Beside the applications already described for described for PCRPi-W, PCRPi-DB can be also used in large-scale studies aimed to understand PPIs at interactome-level and derive common features.
pcrpidb.in: The repository can be browsed and queried in many different ways. Each one of them clearly stated in its help page.
pcrpidb.out: The structural information queried can be visualized using a bespoken molecular visualizer and a series of tables listing the data in a comprehensive manner.

pcpriw.title: PCPRi-W
pcpriw.main: The Presaging Critical Residues in Protein interfaces Webservice is a computational, machine-learning, approach designed to predict hot-spots in protein interfaces. Hot-spot are the residues contributing the most to the binding energy of the interactions. PCRPi-W relies in the integration of physical, sequence, and structural-based information that have been shown to better depict the nature of hot-spot residues.
pcpriw.aim: The tool is directed to users aiming to detect residues of interest for directed mutagenesis, structure-based protein design, or to derive chemicals mimicking critical residues in the interface.
pcpriw.in: The mandatory input is a PDB coordinate file of a protein-protein complex. This file can be either uploaded or directly picked from the Protein Data Bank. Some supplementary parameters can be tweaked in order to fit the user's needs.
pcpriw.out: Mutiple files are provided to users. A part from the original PDB file, a remediated PDB file where quality checks have been perfomed and a B-factor substituted PDB file are provided. Files listing the atomic interactions at the interface of the selected chain and containing a list of predicted hot spot residues ranked by probability are also given to users for download.
